Charming, but very generic movie.

The story has too much sideplots going on, feels like 3-4 screenplays condensed into one: the makers try to mix some classic Karate Kid references with modern, fresh ideas, with a former boxer who tries a reboot of his past successes, with a Chinese boy in an alien country, a new school and with new acquaintances, and you get quite a nostalgic recycling of an all too well known and predictable story taking place at the Big Apple of 2025. 

Despite all the known ingrediences and rushed plot developments, this movie is still quite entertaining. 

For fans a one-time watch.

From the moment it was announced, my expectations were sky-high; the hype was basically pulling double shifts. But once I sat down to watch it, reality hit me with a clean "crane kick" to the face: the movie is a straight-up disappointment.

The story recycles the same old formula without adding anything new: new kid in town, predictable romance, stock bully, rushed training arc, guaranteed win. Nothing wrong with the structure itself, but they tried to squeeze everything into just an hour and a half, leaving the film shallow, jumpy, and with zero emotional payoff.

The big selling point the crossover between the two worlds— had real potential, even if nobody actually asked for it. I bought into the idea… until the execution made it fall apart. The movie opens with a quick explanation to connect both timelines, but Mr. Han vanishes after the first five minutes. From there, we jump straight into the protagonist arriving in New York, struggling to adjust you know, the usual. Nothing surprising.

Then, after a full hour of lukewarm buildup, the movie suddenly tries to deliver the BIG FINAL FIGHT… in the last 25 minutes. And yes, Daniel LaRusso drops in during the final twenty like a last-minute firefighter trying to save the plot. It feels forced, like a desperate attempt to inject excitement that never shows up.

Honestly, the 2010 "Karate Kid" had far more emotion, development, and charm. This one works only as light background entertainment but falls way short of the hype it created.

Final takeaway: the movie disappoints. It’s fine to kill time, but nowhere near strong enough to carry the legacy or the expectations it promised.

As far as sequels in this franchise goes this is probably the best one but by no means is it good. It has the same problems all the other ones had but it functions enough as a overall story. The editing is ok. It certainly gets creative at times with it's transitions out of nowhere at times. Overall the biggest problem lies in the fact it has way too many subplots going on just like the others and retreads the same water of the first one. His subplot with his Mom feels pointless. The romance, moving to a new place, the tournament all feels too familiar at this point. The big chunk of the first half is him training the Dad and it feels like it takes too much focus off of him. And why woud he need to learn but be trained in the scond half? I get he's super talented already but still it just feels weird. The bully, Jackie Chan and Daniel showing up all feels forced in as well. The film up until the point Daniel shows up actually has some rhythm and flow but he feels so forced and it just goes downhill. Than they mix the training montage with the tournament as well so it feels jumpy a bit and by that point were just coasting. It doesn't really justify Daniel being there. Everything else though isn't bad for what it's worth. The new setting is nice, the direction is decent, and the fights aren't bad. They feel a bit too over the top at points like were watching Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon and not Karate Kid though. All the characters are likeable enough but it's everyone we've already seen before and nothing really new at all here. If you've seen any of the others than you've seen this one. But I will say it is more grounded in reality than some of the others. The villians aren't as cartoonish, and they are all likeable. But still skip it. I don't really know where they go from here with this. Wasn't needed and nothing is needed after.

As a huge fan of the Karate Kid/Cobra Kai franchise, I was super excited when this movie was announced after the success of the TV show. Once the trailer was released, it looked like a fun movie that starred both Jackie Chan and Ralph Macchio with a new Karate Kid in Ben Wang. Unfortunately, once I actually got to watching this movie, I was very disappointed. Throughout the whole movie, it felt like something was missing, things that made the first few movies memorable and charming. The editing was trying too hard with fancy transitions, trying to cater to younger generations. The real big thing that was missing was the development of characters, which I found was pretty much non existent. There was no real moments where we saw the characters grow and have heartfelt moments. The jokes fell flat, unlike the great moments we saw in Cobra Kai. I don't think any of this has to do with the actors, but more so to the writers. I do have to give the choreography some credit, because some of the stunts were quite incredible, although feeling a little unrealistic. To me, this movie was a missed opportunity, not capitalizing on the amazing job they did with Cobra Kai. The best scene in the whole movie was the ending where William Zabka made a cameo appearance at the end, and made a few jokes. This may have signalled that the formula and franchise of the Karate Kid may be on its last legs.

So, this was a completely unnecessary movie. This Karate Kid, like several other remakes before it, has recycled trope per trope the essence of the classic 80s original, that you PLEASE should watch that instead than this total slob of Hollywood cash grabbiness. Souless, lazy and without any heart - a young boy moves to an unfamiliar place and gets mentored in martial arts to stand up to their bullies and get the girl. Every plot point was so predictable and bland, that I don’t have to watch it to know where it starts, goes and ends. The villain is incredibly one-note as a vague debt collector crew that also does karate and starts fights and also is in an on and off again thing for our love interest… Even a freaking SAT tutor is somehow a bestie, or the mom character suddenly announces speaking English in a predominantly Mandarin household and upbringing just because they are moving to New York. Nothing makes sense, every little thing is micromanaged to get the most bang for your buck, and I am sick of it. I didn’t get any goosebumps from the fights, archs, really anything… thankfully I was with other people to laugh and make fun. This contributed a NEGATIVE score to my viewing catalogue, and I wasted my time. We shoe in Jackie Chan and Daniel-San to be mentors for the 150th time with random jargon and no build up to any camaraderie at all. The only interesting dynamic that REALLY could have been the movie was Joshua Jackson as this lovable former boxer dad and our main protagonist coaching him for the tournament - now THAT could have been a different and intriguing angle that hasn’t been done before.   If the film had no relation to the Karate Kid franchise, just had the trio from the first half as the stars, and tightened up its foundational storytelling, this could have been a serviceable film with decent cinematography. But nope, don’t bother and please move on.
